A complete bibliography and repository of Sheldon I. Pollock's scholarly work.

Home Search Annotate me

Bibliography by Alex Gil. Works shared by the author, Sheldon I. Pollock. Site built using Ed, a Jekyll theme designed by Alex Gil.

Sheldon I. Pollock.
a complete bibliography

Chapters

  1. Pollock, Sheldon I. “Introduction: An Intellectual History of Rasa.” In A Rasa Reader: Classical Indian Aesthetics, edited by Sheldon I. Pollock. New York: Columbia U. Press, 2018.

  2. ———. “Aufsätze: What Should a Classical Library of India Be?” In Geschichte Der Germanistik Historische Zeitschrift Für Die Philologien., edited by Christoph König, Marcel Lepper, and Wallstein-Verlag. Göttingen: Wallstein Verlag, 2018. | Download PDF.

  3. ———. “Einleitung.” In Kritische Philologie: Essays Zu Literatur, Sprache Und Macht in Indien Und Europa, edited by Christoph König, translated by Brigitte Schöning, 7–15. Philologien. Göttingen: Wallstein-Verl, 2015. | Download PDF.

  4. ———. “Introduction.” In World Philology, edited by Sheldon I. Pollock, Benjamin A. Elman, and Ku-ming Kevin Chang. Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press, 2015. | Download PDF.

  5. ———. “What Was Philology in Sanskrit?” In World Philology, edited by Benjamin A. Elman, Ku-ming Kevin Chang, and Sheldon I. Pollock. Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press, 2015. | Download PDF.

  6. ———. “Indian Classicity.” In Civilisation: Perspectives from the Engelsberg Seminar 2013, edited by Kurt Almqvist and Alexander Linklater, 61–69. Stockholm: Axel and Margaret Ax:son Johnson Foundation, 2014. Reprinted, with emendations, as “The Alternative Classicism of Classical India.” | Download PDF.

  7. ———. “Cosmopolitanism, Vernacularism, and Premodernity.” In Global Intellectual History, edited by Samuel Moyn and Andrew Sartori, 59–80. Columbia University Press, 2013. Selections from The Language of the Gods in the World of Men: Sanskrit, Culture, and Power in Premodern India

  8. ———. “Praśasti: A Small Note on a Big Topic.” In Rajamahima: C. Rajendran Congratulatory Volume, edited by N. K. Sundareswaran, 21–39. Calicut University Sanskrit. Calicut: U. of Calicut Press, 2013. | Download PDF.

  9. ———. “From Rasa Seen to Rasa Heard.” In Aux Abords De La Clairière: Études Indiennes Et Comparées En l’Honneur De Charles Malamoud, edited by Silvia D’Intino and Caterina Guenzi, 189–207. Érudites De l’Ecole Pratique Des Hautes Etudes. Brepols, 2012. | Download PDF.

  10. ———. “Rasa after Abhinava.” In Saṃskṛta-Sādhutā ‘Goodness of Sanskrit’: Studies in Honour of Professor Ashok Aklujkar, edited by Chikafuma Watanabe, Michele Desmarais, and Yoshichika Honda, 287–303. Delhi: Motilal Banarsidass, 2012. https://digitalcommons.unomaha.edu/facultybooks/4.

  11. ———. “Towards a Political Philology: D. D. Kosambi and Sanskrit.” In Unsettling the Past: Unknown Aspects and Scholarly Assessments of D.D. Kosambi, edited by Meera Kosambi. Ranikhet: Permenant Black, 2012. Originally published in Economic and Political Weekly. | Download PDF.

  12. ———. “The Revelation of Tradition: Śruti, Smrti, and the Sanskrit Discourse of Power.” In Boundaries, Dynamics And Construction Of Traditions In South Asia, edited by Federico Squarcini, 2nd ed., 41–62. London: Anthem Press, 2011. https://doi.org/10.7135/UPO9781843313977.003. Corrected and revised reprint. | Download PDF.

  13. ———. “Introduction.” In Forms of Knowledge in Early Modern Asia: Explorations in the Intellectual History of India and Tibet, 1500-1800, edited by Sheldon I. Pollock. Durham, NC: Duke University Press, 2011. | Download PDF.

  14. ———. “Sanskrit Studies in the US.” In Sixty Years of Sanskrit Studies, edited by R. Tripathi, 2: Other Countries:259–310. New Delhi: DK Printworld, 2011. | Download PDF.

  15. ———. “The Languages of Science in Early Modern India.” In Forms of Knowledge in Early Modern Asia: Explorations in the Intellectual History of India and Tibet, 1500-1800, edited by Sheldon I. Pollock. Durham, NC: Duke University Press, 2011. Indian edition Delhi: Manohar, 2011. | Download PDF.

  16. ———. “Comparison without Hegemony.” In The Benefit of Broad Horizons: Intellectual and Institutional Preconditions for a Global Social Science : Festschrift for Bjorn Wittrock on the Occasion of His 65th Birthday, edited by Hans Joas and Barbro Sklute Klein, 185–204. Leiden: Brill, 2010. http://booksandjournals.brillonline.com/content/9789004192874. | Download PDF.

  17. ———. “What Was Bhaṭṭa Nāyaka Saying? The Hermeneutical Transformation of Indian Aesthetics.” In Epic and Argument in Sanskrit Literary History: Essays in Honor of Robert P. Goldman, edited by Sheldon I. Pollock, 143–84. New Delhi: Manohar Publishers & Distributors, 2010. | Download PDF.

  18. ———. “Cross-Currents: Conversion.” In The Longman Anthology of World Literature, edited by David Damrosch, Vol. B. New York: Pearson Longman, 2009.

  19. ———. “Translating the Bhagavad-Gita.” In The Longman Anthology of World Literature, edited by David Damrosch, 2nd ed., A:851–53. New York: Pearson Longman, 2009.

  20. ———. “Zukunftsphilologie?” In Geschichte Der Germanistik Mitteilungen, edited by Christoph König and Marcel Lepper, 25–50. Göttingen: Wallstein Verlag, 2009. German translation of "Future Philology?"

  21. ———. “Early South Asia.” In The Longman Anthology of World Literature, edited by David Damrosch, Vol. A. New York: Pearson Longman, 2009.

  22. ———. “Vernacular Revolutions.” In The Longman Anthology of World Literature, edited by David Damrosch, Vol. C. New York: Pearson Longman, 2009.

  23. ———. “The World the Mughals Made.” In The Longman Anthology of World Literature, edited by David Damrosch, 2nd ed. Vol. D. New York: Pearson Longman, 2009.

  24. ———. “The Folk and Their Tales.” In The Longman Anthology of World Literature, edited by David Damrosch, Vol. E. New York: Pearson Longman, 2009.

  25. ———. “Indian Knowledge and the Problem of Early Modernity.” In Forms of Knowledge in India, edited by Suresh Raval, 19–36. New Delhi: Pencraft International, 2008.

  26. ———. “Literary Culture and Manuscript Culture in Precolonial India.” In Literary Cultures and the Material Book, edited by Simon Eliot. The British Library Studies in the History of the Book. London: British Library, 2007. Reprinted in The History of the Book in South Asia, ed. Francesca Orsini (London: Ashgate, 2013).

  27. ———. “The Languages of Science in Early-Modern India.” In Expanding and Merging Horizons: Contributions to South Asian and Cross-Cultural Studies in Commemoration of Wilhelm Halbfass, edited by Karin Preisendanz. Denkschriften / Österreichische Akademie Der Wissenschaften. Philosophisch-Historische Klasse ; Beiträge Zur Kultur- Und Geistesgeschichte Asiens. Vienna: Austrian Academy of Sciences Press, 2007.

  28. ———. “Empire and Imitation.” In Lessons of Empire: Imperial Histories and American Power, edited by Craig J. Calhoun, Frederick Cooper, and Kevin W. Moore, 175–88. New York: New Press, 2006. | Download PDF.

  29. ———. “Power and Culture Beyond Ideology and Identity.” In Margins of Writing, Origins of Cultures, edited by Seth L Sanders, 277–87. Oriental Institute Seminars. Chicago: Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago, 2006.

  30. ———. “The Revelation of Tradition: Śruti, Smrti, and the Sanskrit Discourse of Power.” In Boundaries, Dynamics And Construction Of Traditions In South Asia, edited by Federico Squarcini, 41–62. Florence: Florence University Press, 2005. https://doi.org/10.7135/UPO9781843313977.003.

  31. ———. “Axialism and Empire.” In Axial Civilizations and World History, edited by Jóhann Páll Árnason, S. N. Eisenstadt, and Björn Wittrock, 397–450. Jerusalem Studies in Religion and Culture. Leiden; Boston: Brill, 2005. | Download PDF.

  32. ———. “Ratnaśrījñāna.” In Encyclopaedia of Indian Wisdom: Prof. Satya Vrat Shastri Felicitation Volume, edited by Satyavrat Sastri and Rāmakaraṇa Śarmā, 637–43. Delhi: Bharatiya Vidya Prakashan, 2005.

  33. ———. “A New Philology: From Norm-Bound Practice to Practice-Bound Norm in Kannada Intellectual History.” In South-Indian Horizons: Felicitation Volume for Francois Gros on the Occasion of His 70th Birthday, edited by Jean-Luc Chevillard, 389–406. Publications Du Département d’Indologie. Pondichéry: Institut Franc̨ais de Pondichéry, [and] École Franc̨aise d’Extrême-Orient, 2004. | Download PDF.

  34. ———. “The Transformation of Culture-Power in Indo-Europe, 1000-1300.” In Eurasian Transformations, Tenth to Thirteenth Centuries: Crystallizations, Divergences, Renaissances, edited by Johann Arnason and Björn Wittrock, 247–78. Medieval Encounters. Leiden: Brill, 2004. https://brill.com/view/title/12032. | Download PDF.

  35. ———. “Introduction.” In Literary Cultures in History: Reconstructions from South Asia, edited by Sheldon I. Pollock, 1–38. Berkeley: University of California Press, 2003. Italian translation, “Dalla storia letteraria alla cultura letteraria nella storia.” In Verso l‘India, Oltre l‘India: Scritti e ricerche sulle tradizioni intellettuali sudasiatiche, ed. Federico Squarcini. Milan: Mimesis, 2002, pp. 55-73. | Download PDF.

  36. ———. “Sanskrit Literary Culture from the Inside Out.” In Literary Cultures in History: Reconstructions from South Asia, edited by Sheldon I. Pollock, 39–130. Berkeley: University of California Press, 2003. | Download PDF.

  37. ———. “Ex Oriente Nox: Indologie Im Nationalsozialistischen Staat.” In Jenseits Des Eurozentrismus: Postkoloniale Perspektiven in Den Geschichts- Und Kulturwissenschaften, edited by Sebastian Conrad and Shalini Randeria, 335–71. Frankfurt am Main; New York: Campus Verlag, 2002.

  38. Pollock, Sheldon I., Dipesh Chakrabarty, Homi Bhabha, and Carol Breckenridge. “Introduction: Cosmopolitanisms.” In Cosmopolitanism, edited by Carol Breckenridge, 1–14. A Millenial Quartet Book. Durham, NC: Duke University Press, 2002. | Download PDF.

  39. Pollock, Sheldon I. “’Aja’s Lament,’ a Translation of Kālidāsa’s Raghuvaṃśa Chapter 8, with Annotations.” In Ancient Indian Literature: An Anthology, edited by T. R. S. Sharma, 2:421–31. New Delhi: Sahitya Akademi, 2000. | Download PDF.

  40. ———. “The Sanskrit Cosmopolis, A.D. 300 – 1300: Transculturation, Vernacularization, and the Question of Ideology.” In Ideology and Status of Sanskrit: Contributions to the History of the Sanskrit Language, edited by Jan E. M. Houben, 197–247. Leiden: Brill, 1996.

  41. ———. “Philology, Literature, Translation.” In Translating, Translations, Translators From India To The West, edited by Enrica Garzilli, 111–31. Harvard Oriental Series, Opera Minora. Cambridge: Harvard University Press, 1996. | Download PDF.

  42. ———. “Rāmāyaṇa and Public Discourse in Medieval India.” In Studies in Jaina Art and Iconography and Allied Subjects in Honour of U. P. Shah, edited by R. T. Vyas, 141–59. Baroda: Oriental Institute, 1996.

  43. ———. “Making History: Kalyāṇi, A.d. 1008.” In M.S. Nagaraja Rao Felicitation Volume, 559–76. Bangalore, 1995. | Download PDF.

  44. ———. “In Praise of Poets: On the History and Function of the Kavipraśaṃsā.” In Ānandabhāratī. Dr. K. Krishnamoorthy Felicitation Volume, edited by B. Channakeshava and H. V. Nagaraja Rao, 443–57. Mysore: DVK Murthy, 1995.

  45. ———. “Deep Orientalism? Notes on Sanskrit and Power Beyond the Raj.” In Orientalism and the Postcolonial Predicament: Perspectives on South Asia, edited by Carol Appadurai Breckenridge and Peter van der Veer, 76–133. South Asia Seminar Series. Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, 1993.

  46. ———. “Introduction.” In The Rāmāyaṇa of Vālmīki: An Epic of Ancient India, Vol III: Aranyakāṇḍa., edited by Robert P. Goldman and Sheldon I. Pollock. Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press, 1990. https://muse.jhu.edu/book/49040/.

  47. ———. “The Idea of Śāstra in Traditional India.” In Shastric Traditions In Indian Arts: Texts, edited by Anna L. Dallapiccola and S. Zingel-Avé Lallemant, 17–26. Wiesbaden: Steiner, 1989.

  48. ———. “Playing By the Rules: Śāstra and Sanskrit Literature.” In Shastric Traditions In Indian Arts: Texts, edited by Anna L. Dallapiccola and S. Zingel-Avé Lallemant, 301–12. Wiesbaden: Steiner, 1989. | Download PDF.

  49. ———. “Introduction.” In The Rāmāyaṇa of Vālmīki: An Epic of Ancient India, Vol II: Ayodhyakāṇḍa., edited by Robert P. Goldman, translated by Sheldon I Pollock, 1–76. Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press, 1986. https://muse.jhu.edu/book/49122. | Download PDF.

  50. ———. “The Rāmāyaṇa Text and the Critical Edition.” In The Rāmāyaṇa of Vālmīki: An Epic of Ancient India, Vol I: Bālakāṇḍa, edited by Robert P. Goldman, 82–93. Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press, 1984. https://muse.jhu.edu/book/49122.

  51. ———. “Text-Critical Observations on Vālmīki Rāmāyaṇa.” In Sternbach Felicitation Volume, 317–25. Lucknow: Akhila Bharatiya Sanskrit Parishad, 1981. | Download PDF.
